Input.threadtitle: How do we know that the Laws of Physics are the Same Anywhere in the Universe?
Input.posts:
How do we know that the laws of physics are the same anywhere in the Universe? I think this was mentioned in the last video lecture of the week 6 and the course. Is this based on scientific evidence? Or can we prove it mathematically? Or is it ultimately based on faith (like in Carl Sagan's 'punchline' in his 'Contact' story / novel / movie)?
Upvotes:
1
Nice question. I guess that we can't be 100% sure in all of physics, even in the most trivial things ! ( remember how Einstein changed our view on something we thought to be so obvious and intuitive? ) We can only judge based on the experiments we do, and the results we have so far. And we don't see it as the 'correct' result , but as the 'nearest to the truth' result.... After all, nothing can be taken for granted in physics :) That's just my opinion, correct me if I'm wrong.
Upvotes:
2
I have seen some theories about different laws of physics in distant, perhaps unobserved parts of the universe (where light has not reached us yet). Also heard about laws of physics changing with time. Paul Davies of Macquarie University in Australia proposed 'a slowing down' of light. I wonder if this theory has been laid to rest yet?
Upvotes:
0
That would not be a different law in different places. It would be a modification of General Relativity, several of which have been proposed. Essentially, gravity on really large scales, like gravity clusters or above, would deviate from Newtonian or Einsteinian values. The inverse square law begins to weaken, or maybe strengthen. As far as changing with time, it would be so slow we'd have to check back in 10,000 or 100,000 years and remeasure everything. Somebody could leave a post-it note for future scientists to remind them. The really bizarre one is that time does not exist, accepted by more physicists than you'd think. But why do we grow old, or things decay? 'Not only is the universe stranger than we think, it is stranger than we can think.' J.B.S. Haldane.
Upvotes:
0

Instructor's Post

Luckily, this hasn't been the case so far, but we can't use a lack of found evidence to rule out the possibility that it is true, especially when we're talking about something with the size and age of our universe.

Input.threadtitle: Lecture 7-3 Spill Over Effect
Input.posts:
The explanation in the lecture makes it seem that the dimensions of the image of a star are due to effects in the detector: that light striking one pixel is spilling over into others and that the spread of light from bright point sources, such as stars or QSOs, is greater than for dimmer ones. Actually for a satellite telescope the spread of light is due only to the diffraction of light. Whenever light goes through an aperture, like the pinhole of a pinhole camera or the opening of a telescope, a parallel beam of light as you would have from an extremely distant point source of light spreads outward in a radially symmetric manner to form an :airy disk surrounded by symmetrical diffraction rings. This is an interference effect of the points on the wave front in the aperture acting like point sources of waves. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffraction#Circular_aperture http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airy_disk The next thing is that the shape of the intensity curve caused by diffraction (the point spread function) is the same for all stars and other point sources in an image (provided our telescope can focus the entire image equally well, which isn't always true). It doesn't matter how bright or dim any particular source is. Bright stars only seem to be bigger. Since the shape of the curve is the same for all, the curve of bright stars have a higher peak value in the center of the airy disk Therefore, since the point spread function has the same shape for all stars in the image, brighter ones remain above the detection level of the detector including any background flux and noise over a larger radius than dimmer ones and, therefore, appear larger. Light spilling over from one pixel to another only happens when the pixels get saturated and, like overflowing buckets, can no longer hold all of the electrons liberated by striking photons. It results in blooming. I don't know if the long faint diagonal streak from lower left to upper right in the image of 3C273 in lecture 7-2 (not the jet) is blooming or not. Blooming normally occurs preferentially in the direction in which the contents of pixels are shifted in the process of reading out the detector. This long streak doesn't appear to be straight down columns of pixels or straight across rows, which is what I would expect to see from blooming, but I don't know how the Chandra detector works. Actually it looks more like a diffraction spikeone might get in an optical telescope from something long and thin across the light path of the telescope, Brad Walter

Our data analysis has NOT used these corrections, because they usually amount to only a few percent. Furthermore, because of the sensitivity of these detectors, there is a phenomenon called 'pile-up' which, as you suggest, does strange things to the central part of the image of a very bright source. The 'readout streak' you see running diagonally across the image stems from the fact that while the frame is being read out, the instrument is still taking data. It's like a 'bucket brigade' which then assigns the 'wrong' pixel position to the new data. It's like a 'bucket brigade' which then assigns the 'wrong' pixel position to the new data.
